section.para: The civilized and well-kept lands of &nation_name; are inhospitable to barbarian tribes. Barbarism and brutishness are frowned upon universally across the country, and many barbarians would find it a challenge to be welcomed or to fit in. As there are no naturally occurring tribes in the valley, most barbarians trace their origins elsewhere on the continent. In particular, they thrive in the blazing sands of &desert_kingdom; and in the gladiatorial pits of &cliffs_nation;.

In &desert_kingdom;, fire-blooded &firepeople; are the warriors of nomadic tribes who roam the desert, never staying in one place for too long as they consider it their duty to safeguard their home and its culture. Though they may feel the bloodlust of battle, many are pragmatists and some fund the efforts of their tribes by working as mercenaries. Others may be outcasts or seekers of gold and glory looking to start a new life in a land different from what they have known.

&cliffs_nation_person; barbarians frequently rise to great ranks in the warrior culture of their homeland. There, where power and determination are revered, barbarians can live akin to nobility. However, feats of greatness must be constantly proven, and one can only rise so high without a worthy tale of one's own. To this end, many leave &cliffs_nation; to travel the continent in search of fame and honor. But for each glorified warrior, there are many defeated ones in his wake, and some among them are barbarians looking to redeem their names in a new land.

As a cultural capital, &nation_name;—and in particular the central cities—holds performance and entertainment in high esteem and demand. One of the central cities, &arts_city;, is completely dedicated to the betterment and enjoyment of the arts, and any performer, new or veteran, will find opportunity there. From frenetic street festivals, to the studious halls of &arts_college;, to the crystalline elegance of the &hitheater; amphitheater, there is no limit to the passions of &arts_city;'s citizens. This intensity has even produced a saying known throughout the nation: no great performer will forever die so long as there is music in &arts_city;.

Even outside of &arts_city;, a performer has many opportunities to excel. Politicians, storeowners, and merchant guilds are all keenly aware of the impact a charismatic face can have on one's audience, and many seek the services of skilled spokesmen. Travelers, far from their homes, find comfort in local song and art even in a land so distant. And a rural life may become grim indeed without wanderers who tell tales or sing songs of grand excitement and adventure.

Although outwardly &nation_name; may seem thoroughly secular and unaffiliated, its history and government are steeped in religion, and many faiths have large temples and congregations here. The temples of Abadar, Shelyn, and Cayden Cailean hold particularly strong political influence, and many of their clerics become officiaries in the grand courts of &law_city; or the wild streets of &arts_city;. But for every cleric who wields the might of cities, there are a thousand others dedicated to more personal endeavors.

Clerics of many faiths, but especially of Sarenrae, Pharasma, and Erastil, roam the cities and countryside performing good works and aiding public services. Some heed a call to protect their loved ones, and join the &police;—a calling often heard by the faithful of Iomedae. Others still seek scholarship in the &library; or &arts_college;, or to study the mysterious and powerful relic shrines that dot the country.

The bounteous lands of the valley of &valley_name; are full of marvelous phenonmena and natural resources, and there is great need for those who would steward those resources correctly. As a result, the druidic population of &nation_name; is not just composed of local druids, but also of those who have traveled long distances to experience the wonders of the valley. In particular, the nation has a considerable influx of druids from &forest_nation; even those of the reclusive &beast_tribes;. Once in the country, druids tend to pursue their own goals as wanderers, members of a druidic micro-community, or even as members of larger organizations for—or perhaps against—the government.

The druidic micro-communities are groups of druids that tend to gather together at sites of particular spiritual significance. There, they tend to flora and fauna of the area and ensure that the site is preserved against any who would do it harm. The &falls_druids; are especially well known to locals and tourists for their protection of the &falls; area, and are perhaps more famous than the druids would like.

Druids that are members of larger organizations tend to work with a temple or the government. There they perform local functions such as ensuring that the harbors and rivers are maintained, and giving advance warning for weather. They may also act as members of committees that perform environmental advisories and studies for government projects. Not all organizations are so friendly towards the smooth operation of local and national government, however. One particularly infamous group, known as the &bad_druids;, are publicly a pro-nature lobbying group, but are widely known to perform anti-civilization acts such as magically weakening the foundations of buildings, defacing directories and road signs, and planting trees in non-designated zones.

Martial prowess is a much sought after skill in &nation_name; and those who are gifted will find many opportunities to display their strengths. Although there is no formal army, the &police; is always looking for those of sharp mind and strong arm to help keep the peace. Because of their limited manpower, the police have learned to fight smart, and they employ a wide range of skilled combat researchers and engineers to develop new tactics and equipment. Fighters looking to earn more than the govnerment is willing to pay might prefer to take on the role of bodyguard or strongman for a wealthy noble or shop owner. Others still may prefer to take a riskier path and bring their feats to the stage as combat performers —masquerading their deadly arts as performance pieces or sport in the &stadium; in &arts_city;. Outside of the central cities, those skilled in combat and with good knowledge of the land excel as hunters or guards for villages and trade caravans.

Monks seeking purification and enlightenment through order and community may find themselves at home in the central cities. There they have the opportunity to participate as good samaritans via public works. There is only one official monk sect in the nation, the &monk_sect;. They are a sect sworn to poverty and truth. In addition to the good works they do for the communities around the country, they also act as a counter-lobby to the economic elite of &nation_name;. Although there is only one official sect, many of the librarians in the &library; are monks who worship Irori. Regardless of affiliation, martial skill and spiritual leadership are valued traits all around the nation. Whether as enforcers for the &police;, covert bodyguards, performers, or guides for those who wander from the path to enlightenment, a monk will not find herself without a purpose for long.

Although the nation was founded as the result of a crusade, its economic and political success have made the environment less than welcoming for holy knights. Paladins are seen by many government and mercantile leaders as unpredictable and potentially disruptive zealots who might damage the smooth functioning of the nation. Even among the temples represented in the senate, most choose to call their paladins to other parts of the world. However, there are many causes worthy of advancement in &nation_name;, and those who can adhere to more tolerant or flexible codes will often find their efforts rewarded. In particular, paladins of Sarenrae and Erastil are often welcomed with open arms for their efforts to be understanding and mend the sufferings of the people. Some members of the &police; are also paladins of Iomedae, and they snuff out crime and corruption with zeal—though always under the careful guidance of their superiors.

But despite the best efforts of the nation's leadership to keep the zealots away, they are not always so successful. There are occasional instances of activism from both clandestine and public groups of divine warriors who vie for greater recognition and political influence for their causes.

Although the valley of &valley_name; is relatively small and geographially isolated, much of its lands have yet to be tamed and its mines have yet to be fully charted. The wilds can be dangerous, and as the people of &nation_name; forge ever outwards and downwards they are in need of those who can provide guidance through the unknown perils. Explorers and hunters ply the forests and mountains for quarry of bear, wolves, mountain lions, or perhaps an Aurumvorax caught feasting on a surface ore vein. The brave or foolhardy willing to delve deep into the caverns below the nation on behalf mining operations may find foes stranger still, but great bounty awaits those who fulfull their duties successfully.

In the parts of the country fresh with civilization, seasoned woodsmen and outland police patrols protect fledgling villages and secure survival from season to season. And in the heart of the country, those with connections to the wilds can deal in lucrative exotic pelts, trophies, and other goods. For those who do not wish to exploit their talents for profit from slaughter, there are many men, women, and children who will pay handsomly to see talented animals and their trainers perform in &arts_city;.

Although the central cities are lawful and safe places, a rogue's talents are nonetheless very useful. Merchants and politicians alike can always find a role for someone with quick hands and silent feet, and in a land of tourism and commerce pickpockets and con artists have ample choice of targets if they're willing to take the risk. Some reformed scoundrels might choose to redeem themselves as bounty hunters or undercover agents for the &police;. Others instead opt to live as performers—bringing joy and excitement instead of aggravation and ruin. The &knife_throwers; is particularly well known for taking in those of dubious pasts and repurposing them to more gainful employment as daring, skillful daredevils.
Outside of the central cities, rural life provides fewer opportunities for a rogue, and those who cannot or will not make livings as trappers or hunters often turn to criminal undertakings.

Opportunities of all kinds can appear unexpectedly in &nation_name;, and a sorcerer's innate ability to instanly access the full wealth of her magical strengths is an invaluable tool for responding to sudden windfalls. In the bustling central cities, sorcerers are valued as enchanters in crafting workshops, but they are especially valued in &arts_city;. There, the constantly changing environment of festivals and performances often demands immediate response to crazy schemes and outlandish requests. A company of sorcerers known as &fireworks_co; has specialized in this field, and keeps a sizable retinue of magical adepts on retainer for hire by performers in need.

A sorcerer's natural force of personality also benefits those who choose to employ their powers to further some goal beyond wealth and entertainment. Many sorcerers of celestial and infernal bloodlines take leadership positions both in local government and mercantile operations, where they excel in bringing allies and adversaries under their sway. Others still choose to unleash the full extent of their potential as members of the &police;.

The vast libraries and combined cultural knowledge of the central cities are a great resource to many wizards, and none will struggle to find employment here. The government of &nation_name; employs a huge number of wizards in the &customs_dept;, where they research and approve requests for transit using the country's magical gates. This approval process also involves the charging of keys for the gates and their tranmission to the proper recipients. In exchange for their services and loyalties, the &customs_dept; funds research grants for these wizards and also provides shelter and workspaces.

Craftsman also value skilled wizards, and many vie to employ the best in their workshops. For those who cannot afford a full time enchanter, supply shops offer the end results of the creative process. &magic_supply; is a particularly well known name in &market_city;, and they employ skilled enchanters to fulfill bulk and custom requests for their clients.
